scenario: Breast implant evaluation
Evaluation of saline breast implants. Any age. Initial imaging.
Evaluation of cosmetic silicone breast implants Suspected implant rupture/complication.
Evaluation of non-cosmetic, silicone breast implants. Suspected implant rupture/complication. Any age. Initial imaging prior to Surgical review.
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Suspected breast implant associated anaplastic large-cell lymphoma (BIA-ALCL) (delayed seroma, swelling, mass, pain but no erythema, warmth or skin changes that would raise concern for inflammatory breast cancer or mastitis). Any age. Breast implant of any type. Initial imaging.
modality: US +/- MR C-/ US guided aspiration
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Breast pain
Female with breast pain but no other suspicious clinical features or risk factors in history. Any age.
Female with clinically significant breast pain (focal and noncyclical) and lumpiness or other suspicious feature on exam and/or positive family history or other risk factor.  Initial imaging.
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral  to within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Evaluation of the symptomatic male breast
modality: Evaluation of the symptomatic male breast
priority: Evaluation of the symptomatic male breast
comments: Evaluation of the symptomatic male breast

scenario: Male patient any age with symptoms of gynecomastia and physical examination consistent with gynecomastia or pseudo-gynecomastia. No focal abnormality on exam
Male any age with focal unilateral abnormality /indeterminate palpable breast mass. Initial imaging following breast specialist review
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Male of any age with indeterminate palpable breast mass/ focal unilateral abnormality cancer (suspicious palpable breast mass, axillary adenopathy, nipple discharge, or nipple retraction). Initial imaging.
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

modality: Imaging after mastectomy and breast reconstruction

comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

Palpable breast mass. Female, <40 years of age, initial evaluation.
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral   or Urgent  complete within 2 weeks

scenario: Palpable breast mass. Female, 40 years of age or older, initial evaluation.

Physiologic nipple discharge. Female of any age. Initial imaging examination.

scenario: Pathologic nipple discharge. Male younger than 30 years of age. Initial imaging examination.

Palpable breast mass. Female, younger than 30 years of age, initial evaluation.
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Staging known breast cancer
Breast Multidisciplinary group recommends staging
modality: CT CAP + bone scan or CT PET
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Surveillance, history of breast cancer
Surveillance. Personal history of breast cancer. Asymptomatic. Rule out local recurrence.
comments: Deferrable, time-sensitive imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of a specified target date

scenario: Clinical suspicion of inflammatory breast cancer
comments: Sub-acute, urgent  complete within 1 week or  urgent complete within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Follow up of findings on other imaging modalities
modality: Follow up of findings on other imaging modalities
priority: Follow up of findings on other imaging modalities
comments: Follow up of findings on other imaging modalities

scenario: 2nd look imaging for findings on MRI or CT
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral  or within 6 weeks

scenario: Work up recommended by an MDM
modality: Work up recommended by an MDM
priority: Work up recommended by an MDM
comments: Work up recommended by an MDM

scenario: Further work up, biopsy or imaging recommended by the Breast Multidisciplinary meeting
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Post op seroma
Post operative seroma unable to be drained without imaging guidance
comments: Sub-acute, Urgent  within  48 hrs to 1 week ,  to   non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Follow up
Follow up imaging recommended on previous breast imaging
comments: Deferrable, time-sensitive imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of a specified target date

scenario: Recommended biopsy
Previous breast imaging recommended biopsy for probably malignant or indeterminate lesion (including papilloma)

scenario: Previous breast imaging recommended biopsy for probably benign lesion (suspected fibrocystic changes or fibroadenoma)
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Breast MR Referral Indications
New diagnosis breast cancer
New diagnosis breast cancer with high background risk of undetected disease (e.g. BRCA-1; dense breasts) AND as recommended by MDM
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Invasive ductal cancer where the extent IS clear on mammogram and/or US
Invasive ductal cancer where the extent IS NOT clear on mammogram or US and MR recommended by MDM
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Non-calcified (typically high grade) DCIS to define extent for surgical planning and where recommended by MDM e.g. particularly with dense breasts
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Pre-and post- neoadjuvant chemotherapy, with a view to downstaging the lesion and allowing breast conserving surgery
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Lumpectomy with a positive margin. If multiple positive margins, to move straight to mastectomy and nil MR
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Fixed tumour, ?Invasion to deep fascia and neoadjuvant chemo or radiotherapy to establish a clear margin prior to surgery is being considered. Recommended by MDM
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Breast symptoms evaluation
Pathologic nipple discharge (bloody or serous). No cause identified on DBI and ongoing concerns
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Suspected breast implant associated anaplastic large-cell lymphoma (BIA-ALCL) (delayed seroma, swelling, mass, pain but no erythema, warmth or skin changes that would raise concern for inflammatory breast cancer or mastitis). Any age. Breast implant of any type. Initial imaging.
modality: US +/- MR C-/ US guided aspiration
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Positive axillary node, ?occult breast primary

scenario: Surveillance, screening
High risk screening (BRCAs etc.)
comments: Deferrable, time-sensitive imaging that must be completed within 6-12 weeks of a specified target date

scenario: Follow-up MRI surveillance of women could be considered, where initial presentation with palpable mass (biopsy positive) was occult on mammogram and ultrasound, but visible on MRI.
comments: Deferrable, time-sensitive imaging that must be completed within 6-12 weeks of a specified target date  Specific timeframe preferred, deferrable

scenario: Acute chest pain
Chest pain syndrome - not clear ACS/intermediate probability of CAD
comments: Acute , sub acute, urgent , complete within <24-48 hrs to within 1- 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Low probability coronary artery disease

priority: P4 or P2 if red flags

Hypopituitarism

Hyperthyroidism (high TSH)
Cushing's syndrome (high ACTH)

Precocious puberty
Thyroid

Palpable thyroid nodule, suspicious features (e.g. painless rapid growth over 2-3 months, history of voice change +/or stridor, youth/child, family history of MEN, neck nodes), euthyroid, initial imaging
Palpable thyroid nodule, no suspicious features  for thyroid cancer, euthyroid, initial imaging
Incidental thyroid nodule on CT or MR. TSH normal or elevated and >1.5cm if >35y and >1.0cm if <35y
Incidental thyroid nodule on CT or MR. TSH reduced.
Incidental FDG-avid nodule on PET CT
Suspected goitre. Initial imaging. Obstructive symptoms
Thyrotoxicosis. Initial imaging
Primary hypothyroidism. Initial Imaging
Medullary thyroid cancer on biopsy
Thyroid cancer, surgery considered, anaplastic ca or metastatic disease suspected
Adrenal lesion
No history of malignancy; mass 1-4 cm in diameter. Initial evaluation.
modality: CT, MRI if required for further evaluation.

scenario: No history of malignancy; mass 1-4 cm in diameter.  Follow-up evaluation in 12 months.
modality: CT, MRI if required for further evaluation.

scenario: No history of malignancy; mass >4 cm in diameter.  (If not typical for adenoma, myelolipoma, haemorrhage or simple cyst, consider resection). Clinical review pre-biopsy.
modality: CT, MRI if required for further evaluation.

scenario: History of malignancy; mass > 4 cm in diameter.  Clinical review pre-biopsy.
General
Imaging recommended by MDM
Post op care/complications
Acute shoulder pain
Any aetiology; best initial study, (septic arthritis not-suspected clinically)
X-ray non-contributory.  Persistent significant pain.  Physical examination and history nonspecific.  Next study.
X-ray non-contributory.  Age less than 35 years, suspect labral tear with or without instability on physical examination.
X-ray non-contributory.  Questionable bursitis or long head of biceps tenosynovitis based on clinical findings including physical examination.
Normal x-ray  or x-ray  demonstrates coracoacromial arch osteophytes/syndesmophytes.  Suspect rotator cuff tear/ impingement, over 35 years.
comments: US first investigation. If concern of complete tendon tear especially subscapularis and especially in younger patients, then P3 or less is better

scenario: X-ray non-contributory.  Previous total shoulder arthroplasty.  Suspect rotator cuff tear.
X-ray non-contributory.  Status post prior rotator cuff repair.  Suspect re-tear.
comments: P3. Earlier timeframe better for potential surgical repair. US first

scenario: Chronic shoulder pain
?arthritis ?other
modality: XR, then US if normal XR and cuff tear suspected

scenario: Acute elbow pain
Suspect intra-articular osteocartilaginous body; ossicles on x-ray
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Suspect intra-articular osteocartilaginous body; X-rays NAD
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Suspect occult injury e.g. osteochondral injury; radiographs nondiagnostic.
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Suspect unstable osteochondral injury; radiographs nondiagnostic.
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Suspect mass; radiographs nondiagnostic.
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Suspect chronic epicondylitis, radiographs nondiagnostic.
comments: Deferrable , lowest priority, can wait 12 weeks

scenario: Suspect collateral ligament tear; radiographs nondiagnostic.
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral -or P1 as per comment

scenario: Suspect biceps tendon tear and/or bursitis; radiographs non-diagnostic.
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Suspect nerve abnormality; radiographs nondiagnostic.
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Chronic elbow pain
?arthritis ?other
comments: XR first- further imaging e.g. US,  based on clinician review

scenario: Acute hand and wrist trauma
Suspect acute distal radius fracture. Radiographs normal.  Next procedure.
Comminuted, intra-articular distal radius fracture on radiographs.  Surgical planning.
Suspect acute scaphoid fracture. X-rays normal.  Next procedure.
Suspected occult scaphoid fracture. Initial and repeat x-rays after 10-14 days of casting normal. Continued clinical suspicion of scaphoid fracture.  Next procedure.
comments: P2 i.e.  patient already in cast

scenario: Suspect distal radioulnar joint subluxation.
Suspect hook of the hamate fracture. Initial radiographs normal or equivocal.
comments: CT first and then  MRI  if occult fracture still suspected

scenario: Suspect metacarpal fracture or dislocation.
Suspect gamekeeper injury (thumb MCP ulnar collateral ligament injury).
modality: XR then US if normal XR
comments: XR P1 if NAD,  then US P2>P3

scenario: Chronic wrist pain
With or without prior injury. Best initial study.
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Routine x-rays normal or nondiagnostic. Persistent symptoms. Next study.
comments: Deferrable , lowest priority, can wait 12 weeks

scenario: Routine x-rays normal or nondiagnostic. Suspect arthritis ( other than septic). Next study.
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral  weeks, deferrable to Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Nonspecific arthritis on x-ray. Exclude infection. Next study.
comments: Acute <24 hrs  to Sub-acute, Urgent , complete imaging  within  48 hrs to 1 week of receiving referral , non-deferrable

scenario: Pain on ulnar side, suspect triangular fibrocartilage or lunotriquetral ligament tear. Radiographs normal. Next study.
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: X-rays show positive ulnar variance and irregularity in proximal lunate articular surfaces. Next study.
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: X-rays normal or equivocal. Suspect Kienbock's disease. Next study.
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Kienbock's disease on x-rays. Next study.
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Pain for more than 3 weeks. Suspect occult fracture. Radiographs nondiagnostic. Next study.
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Suspect carpal tunnel syndrome.
modality: Usually none/ XR only if concern of contributory arthritis
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of the hip
Avascular necrosis is suspected clinically.
comments: MRI if XR normal or inconclusive

scenario: Avascular necrosis with femoral head collapse on x-ray of the painful hip
comments: MRI only if requested by subspecialty hip surgeon. Deferrable if no surgery contemplated.

scenario: Chronic hip pain
Initial evaluation for chronic hip pain. First test.
Rapidly increasing hip pain, not typical for usual OA progression
comments: e.g. active inflammatory arthritis and rapid destruction and collapse of the femoral head

scenario: X-rays  negative, suspect osseous or surrounding soft-tissue abnormality, excluding osteoid osteoma.
X-rays negative, suspect osteonecrosis. Includes circumstances in which hip is asymptomatic but osteonecrosis is suspected due to known predisposing factors.
X-rays negative. Suspect osteoid osteoma.
comments: MRI first and if negative consider CT  and bone scan

scenario: X-rays negative, suspect labral tear with or without clinical findings consistent with or suggestive or femoro-acetabular impingement.
X-rays negative or mild osteoarthritis. Suspect referred pain but wish to exclude hip.
X-rays positive, arthritis uncertain type.  Infection not a consideration.
Radiographs positive, suggestive of pigmented villo-nodular synovitis or osteochondromatosis.
Non traumatic knee pain
Child or adult: patellofemoral (anterior) symptoms.  Mandatory minimal initial examination.
Adult: non-trauma, non-tumour, non-localised pain. Mandatory minimal initial examination.
Child or adult: patellofemoral (anterior) symptoms. Initial knee x-rays nondiagnostic (demonstrate normal findings or a joint effusion).
Adult: non-trauma, non-tumour, non-localised pain. Initial knee x-rays nondiagnostic (demonstrate normal findings or a joint effusion).
Adult: patellofemoral (anterior) symptoms. Initial knee x-rays demonstrate degenerative joint disease and/or chondrocalcinosis.

Adult: non-tumour, non-localised pain. Initial knee x-rays demonstrate inflammatory, crystalline, or degenerative joint disease (uni- to tri-compartmental sclerosis, hypertrophic spurs, joint space narrowing, and/or subchondral cysts).
Adult: non-tumour, non-localised pain. Initial knee x-rays demonstrate avascular necrosis.
Adult:  non-tumour, non-localised pain.  Initial knee radiographs x-rays evidence of internal derangement (e.g. Segond fracture, deep lateral femoral notch sign).
Imaging after Total Knee arthroplasty
Pain after TKA: initial evaluation.
Pain after TKA: positive aspiration for infection.
Pain after TKA: positive x-ray for loosening. Negative aspiration for infection.
Pain after TKA:  negative x-ray for loosening. Negative aspiration for infection.
Routine follow-up of asymptomatic patients with TKA.
Chronic ankle pain
Chronic ankle pain of any origin - best initial study.
Multiple sites of degenerative joint disease by ankle x-rays. Next study.
Ankle x-rays normal, suspected osteochondral injury. Next study.
Ankle x-rays normal, suspected tendon abnormality. Next study.
Arthropathy presentation
Acute presentation, flare, or surveillance
Acute ? bone tumour
Screening, first study.
Persistent symptoms, but x-ray negative.
Definitively benign on x-rays (excluding osteoid osteoma).
Clinically suspected osteoid osteoma.
Suspicious for malignant characteristics on x-ray
Acute ? soft tissue tumour
Clinically suspected soft-tissue mass: general.
Mass palpated at a joint.
Soft-tissue mass: limb.
Soft-tissue mass: abdominal or chest wall.
comments: Often CT first to confirm lesion, then MRI for further characterisation

scenario: Calcified soft-tissue mass not definitely benign seen on x-rays.
Negative or nonspecific findings on x-rays in area of palpated mass.
Follow-up of spontaneous soft-tissue haemorrhage in older adults.
Follow up of malignant or aggressive MSK tumours
modality: Follow up of malignant or aggressive MSK tumours
priority: Follow up of malignant or aggressive MSK tumours
comments: Follow up of malignant or aggressive MSK tumours

scenario: Lower-risk patient (low grade). Evaluation for metastatic disease to the lung from musculoskeletal primary.
Higher-risk patient (high grade). Evaluation for metastatic disease to the lung from musculoskeletal primary.
Evaluation for osseous metastatic disease from musculoskeletal primary.
Surveillance for local recurrence.
Osseous tumour  Local recurrence.
Soft-tissue tumour. Local recurrence.
Ataxia
Slowly progressive ataxia, or ataxia of long duration (adult or child).
Cerebrovascular disease
Asymptomatic. Structural lesion on physical examination (cervical bruit) and/or risk factors.
comments: Asymptomatic carotid bruit not routinely imaged

scenario: Epilepsy
Chronic epilepsy, poor therapeutic response. Surgery candidate.
New onset seizure. ETOH, and/or drug related.
New onset seizure. Aged 18 - 40 years.
New onset seizure. Older than age 40.
Focal neurological deficit
Single or multiple focal neurologic deficits.
Headache
Chronic headache. No new features.
Chronic headache with new features.
New headache in patients older than age 60.  Sedimentation rate higher than 55, temporal tenderness.  Suspected temporal arteritis.
comments: May be  nil  imaging if clinically confident of the diagnosis

scenario: Neurodegenerative Disorders
Possible/probable Alzheimer's disease.
Suspected vascular dementia or rapidly progressive dementia or mixed vascular dementia and Alzheimer's disease.
Frontotemporal dementia.
Dementia with Lewy bodies.
Suspected prion disease (Creutzfeldt-Jakob, iatrogenic CJ, or variant CJ)
Suspected normal pressure hydrocephalus.
comments: Depends on clinical setting. In the subacute setting, CT may be helpful for immediate management, with MRI only if needed.

scenario: Suspected Huntington disease
Clinical features suggestive of neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation (NBIA).
Parkinson's disease: typical clinical features and responds to levodopa.
Parkinsonian syndrome: atypical clinical features not responsive to levodopa.
Motor neuron disease.
comments: P3, not deferrable (can be useful occasionally), given the nature of this condition should be done <6 weeks. Spine may be required also.

scenario: Demyelination/MS
Routine 12-month follow up, on medication for MS
Follow up of MS with ?new relapse
Cerebrovascular
Risk for unruptured aneurysm. Positive family history.
comments: MRA>CTA due to radiation and better to have same baselines for follow up

scenario: Proven SAH, negative angiogram, follow-up.
comments: Case by case, some should have repeat DSA in a week, others just MRA or longer interval

scenario: Space occupying lesion
No neurological deficit
Routine follow up glioma/GBM
Follow up of glioma/GBM and considering treatment (e.g. is nodular enhancement enlarging)
Follow up of glioma/GBM with new/worsening symptoms
Congenital disorders
Routine follow up
Hydrocephalus, shunt function
Routine surveillance
Abnormal vaginal bleeding
Postmenopausal vaginal bleeding. First study.
Postmenopausal vaginal bleeding, follow up.
comments: Follow up scan would be at referring clinician’s discretion and time accordingly however would be non-deferable from the specified time.

scenario: Premenopausal vaginal bleeding. First study.
comments: This is a large cohort of pts and individual consideration to cases is needed to determine time frame. If any high-risk clinical factors may need to be triaged P2.

scenario: Premenopausal vaginal bleeding, follow up.
comments: Follow up scan post endometrial sampling or other management may not always be mandatory e.g. after removal of endo polyp. If high clinical risk, then triage 3 or even P2 if symptomatic anaemia.

scenario: Premenopausal vaginal bleeding, follow up of multi-fibroid uterus as per clinician/ radiologist recommendation
comments: Relatively  low risk , e.g. on clinical discretion a follow up of multi-fibroid uterus is required S4.

scenario: Palpable adnexal mass
Reproductive age female (not pregnant). Initial evaluation.
Clinically suspected adnexal mass
Reproductive age female (not pregnant). Initial evaluation.
comments: If  a suspected mass with pain or bleeding then P2, otherwise P3.

scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant) with complex or solid mass detected by pelvic sonography; NOT clearly malignant. Follow-up recommendations.
comments: Can be planned triage as either 6 weeks or 3 months follow up ultrasound depending on clinician recommendation or MDM review.

scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant) with complex or solid mass detected by pelvic sonography getting smaller at short-term follow-up.  (If resolved, no further imaging necessary).
comments: Could defer to a 4 depending on symptoms, clinical risk and tumour markers. Clinician to indicate.

scenario: Reproductive age female (not pregnant) with complex or solid mass that is persistent or enlarging on pelvic sonography at short-term follow-up.
Reproductive age female (not pregnant). Initial sonography demonstrates a large and apparently simple cyst >6 cm in diameter.
comments: Could defer to a P4 depending on symptoms. Clinician to indicate.

scenario: Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea).  Initial evaluation.
Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea) with a simple ovarian cyst >5 cm in diameter by pelvic sonography.
Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea) with a simple ovarian cyst 3-5 cm in diameter seen by pelvic sonography.
Postmenopausal female (>12 months amenorrhea) with a complex or solid adnexal mass seen by pelvic sonography.
Staging of gynaecological cancers
Pre-treatment of ovarian cancer or rule out recurrence
Invasive cancer of the cervix, FIGO stage 1b1 or greater
Endometrial cancer of the uterus
Acute pelvic pain in the reproductive age group
modality: Acute pelvic pain in the reproductive age group
priority: Acute pelvic pain in the reproductive age group
comments: Acute pelvic pain in the reproductive age group

scenario: Gynaecological aetiology suspected, serum β-hCG positive
comments: If ectopic pregnancy suspected - same day imaging

scenario: Gynaecological aetiology suspected, serum β-hCG negative.
comments: Triage depends on clinical indication: acute versus chronic pain, associated bleeding. For example, acute pain ovarian torsion, haemorrhagic cyst etc will need triage P1. However, other pain non-specified could be triage P2. Clinician to indicate urgency.

scenario: Non Gynaecological aetiology suspected, serum β-hCG positive.
comments: Early pregnancy causes of pain not related to pregnancy i.e. UTI, appendicitis, ovarian, gallbladder.

scenario: Pain in pregnancy
2nd or 3rd trimester
comments: Scan to be tailored to location of pain i.e. Maternal adnexa, gallbladder, kidneys, appendix, placenta (abruption) etc. Assessment of foetal wellbeing is always required at a minimum as well unless pain is clearly renal or GB in origin.

scenario: Bleeding in pregnancy
1st trimester, positive pregnancy test
comments: According to HealthPathways, urgency depends on clinical risk factors - if ectopic suspected or bleeding severe may need to be within 24 hours

scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms.
comments: Scan to determine cause of APH i.e. Placenta praevia, vasa praevia, placental abruption may need vaginal ultrasound. Growth assessment can be performed if due.

scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Placenta previa diagnosed before 32 weeks.
comments: Any longer wait-time e.g. P2 should be at clinical discretion - including  where already excluded vasa praevia on previous scan or already diagnosed placenta praevia or low-lying placenta at anatomy scan.

scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Uterine contractions, pain, > 20 weeks
2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Persistent low-lying placenta.
comments: Deferral to P2 at clinical discretion only

scenario: 2nd or 3rd trimester, no other signs or symptoms. Placenta previa, history of caesarean delivery.
comments: Need to exclude placenta accreta. May need transvaginal scan. If first scan triage P1. If placenta accreta already known from a previous scan, then can triage P2 or tailored/planned/32 weeks follow up based on clinician recommendation from previous MDM or other earlier discussions.

scenario: Growth disturbance (risk IUGR)
Risk of IUGR initial evaluation
comments: Risk of foetal  demise if severe and poorly managed.

scenario: Small foetus, low or low normal fluid, follow-up studies
comments: Follow up as per SGA pathway, to be advised by referring clinician..

scenario: Very small foetus, normal fluid, follow-up studies
comments: Follow up as per SGA pathway, to be advised by referring clinician. Non deferable.

scenario: Normal sized foetus, low or absent fluid, follow-up studies
comments: Follow up to be advised by referring clinician. Non deferrable.

scenario: Assessment of gravid cervix
Patient at risk for preterm delivery: 16-24 weeks gestation: cervical length ≥3cm on transvaginal ultrasound scan
comments: standard 2 week follow up screening scan for cervical length 16-24 weeks or as advised by PTB clinic

scenario: Patient at risk for preterm delivery (history of prior preterm birth or multiple gestations): 16-24 weeks gestation: cervix ≤3 cm long by transvaginal ultrasound scan
comments: May need a follow up scan sooner than standard 2-week interval at clinician discretion

scenario: 2nd or third trimester assessment of cervix after 24 weeks
comments: Assessment of cervical cerclage or monitoring of open cervix after 24 weeks gestation. Scan timing at clinician discretion depending on indication.

scenario: Neck mass/lymphadenopathy
Adult presenting with a non-pulsatile solitary neck mass (afebrile).
Adult presenting with multiple neck masses.
Adult with a history of treatment for cancer presenting with a neck mass.
Sino-nasal disease
Uncomplicated rhinosinusitis.
Recurrent acute or chronic rhinosinusitis (possible surgical candidate).
Bilateral sino-nasal polyposis
Sino-nasal obstruction, suspected mass lesion.
Vertigo and hearing loss
Sensorineural hearing loss, acute and intermittent vertigo.
Sensorineural hearing loss, no vertigo.
Conductive hearing loss, to rule out petrous bone abnormality.
Total deafness, cochlear implant candidate, surgical planning.
Fluctuating hearing loss, history of meningitis or to rule out congenital anomaly.
Vertigo, no hearing loss, normal neurological examination.
Cranial neuropathy
Anosmia and abnormalities of the sense of smell.
Weakness or paralysis of the muscles of mastication; sensory abnormalities of the head and neck.
Weakness or paralysis of facial expression.
Palate weakness.
Vocal cord paralysis.
Weakness or paralysis of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
Weakness or paralysis of the tongue.
Perineural spread of tumour.
TMJ dysfunction
No response to non-operative treatment
Dysphagia
Unexplained oropharyngeal dysphagia.
Oropharyngeal dysphagia with an attributable cause.
General neurology
Neurocognitive regression
Developmental delay, cerebral palsy, spinal dysraphism
Macrocephaly-stable,  in otherwise normal child
Progressive macrocephaly
Microcephaly
Seizures
Focal/partial seizure
Seizures with regression or arrest in development
Generalised seizures, no neurology, even if intractable
Headache
Progressive headache without neurological signs or symptoms of raised ICP
Chronic headache with no neurological signs
Ataxia
Slowly progressive ataxia, or ataxia of long duration (adult or child)
Focal neurological deficits
Multiple focal neurologic deficits
Single focal neurologic deficit, sudden onset, stable, or incompletely resolving
Single focal neurologic deficit, sudden onset, progressive
Single focal neurologic deficit, completely resolving
Neuroendocrine
Hypopituitarism
comments: P1 if visual field abnormal, P3 if visual fields normal

scenario: Obesity/eating disorder
Hyperthyroidism (high TSH)
Cushing's syndrome (high ACTH)
Hyperprolactinemia
comments: P1 if abnormal visual fields or ↑prolactin otherwise P3

scenario: Acromegaly/gigantism
Variant 7 - Growth hormone deficiency, growth deceleration, panhypopituitarism
comments: P1 if visual field abnormal, P3 if visual fields normal

scenario: Diabetes insipidus
Pituitary apoplexy
Postoperative sella
Precocious puberty
ENT
Child (up to age 14) presenting with a solitary neck mass or multiple neck masses (afebrile)
Children with uncomplicated acute sinusitis
Children with persistent (acute sinusitis that does not respond to treatment), recurrent, or chronic sinusitis
Children with sinusitis with orbital or intracranial complications
Musculoskeletal
DDH - Child younger than 4 months of age, hip instability or dislocation detected or suspected on exam.
DDH - Child younger than 4 months of age, breech presentation or positive family history, stable hips on exam
DDH - Patient 4 months of age or older, clinically suspicious for DDH (limited abduction or abnormal gait)
Limp - Non-focal clinical examination
Limp - Focal clinical examination (not septic arthritis)
Respiratory
Cystic Fibrosis
comments: Annual + prn CXR. US for portal hypertension age 5 then annual or prn. HRCT age 6.

scenario: Bronchiectasis
Gastrointestinal
IBD work up
IBD extension of disease or symptomatic
IBD perianal region
IBD collection or phlegmon suspected
Intermittent nonbilious vomiting since birth.
New onset projectile nonbilious vomiting.
Urology and Nephrology
UTI
Antenatal renal dilatation
Oncology
Post treatment
Urology
Uncomplicated UTI, age <6 months, first episode
Recurrent infections (>/=2 episodes of culture positive UTI or high suspicion previous episode/s missed)
Gross, painless haematuria and no evident cause
Persistent, isolated microscopic haematuria on urine microscopy (>1 year) without proteinuria and increased urinary calcium or calcium creatinine ratio
Dipstick positive proteinuria and confirmed on PCR on early morning sample, when child is well
Enuresis - secondary
Acute respiratory illness
CXR pneumonia follow up.
comments: P3 if CXR showed mass like pneumonia, looked like pneumonia but with no signs of infection, or looked like a pneumonia with pleural fluid.  P4 if standard typical pneumonia (AV)

scenario: Chronic dyspnoea- suspected pulmonary origin
Any age, positive physical examination.
Older than age 40, negative physical examination.
Younger than age 40, negative physical exam. Positive with other symptoms, severe dyspnoea, or other risk factors.
Younger than age 40, negative physical examination.
Any age, non-revealing or non-diagnostic clinical, standard radiography, and laboratory studies.
comments: Duration and severity dependant. P3 if symptoms <2 months or >2months if progressive.  P4 if >2 months

scenario: Suspected ILD
Chronic cough
Suspected bronchiectasis
Haemoptysis
Persistent/recurrent haemoptysis >40 years old +/- smoking history
comments: P2 CXR first then P3 CT if CXR normal

scenario: ?Rib fracture
Adult - any age
comments: CXR only if surgical emphysema or asymmetrical signs

scenario: Solitary pulmonary nodule on CXR
Nodule ≥ 1 cm and </= 3cms, low clinical suspicion for cancer.
comments: P3 if no previous imaging P4 if stable

scenario: Nodule ≥ 1 cm and </= 3cms, moderate to high clinical suspicion for cancer.
comments: Consider direct referral for  CT PET if resectable on CXR

scenario: Nodule ≤ 1 cm, low clinical suspicion for cancer.
Nodule ≤ 1 cm, moderate to high clinical suspicion for cancer.
Lung cancer staging
Lung mass on CXR (or other imaging modality) and imaging appearances suggest curative
Lung mass on CXR (or other imaging modality) and imaging appearances suggest non-curative
Routine admission and pre-operative chest radiography
modality: Routine admission and pre-operative chest radiography
priority: Routine admission and pre-operative chest radiography
comments: Routine admission and pre-operative chest radiography

scenario: Asymptomatic; history and physical unremarkable.
Acute cardiopulmonary findings by history or physical.
Chronic cardiopulmonary disease in the elderly (age >70), previous chest radiograph within 6 months available.
Chronic cardiopulmonary disease in the elderly (age >70), previous chest radiograph within 6 months not available.
Pleural disease
Pleural effusion, probably benign
Pleural effusion, possibly malignant
modality: CXR, +/-US and drainage, +/- CT (as per comment)
comments:
Large effusion- P2 CXR, and , US and drainage 
Small effusion or PHx of cancer -. P2 CXR  + CT

scenario: Low back pain
Uncomplicated acute low back pain and/or radiculopathy, nonsurgical presentation.  No red flags*
comments: (See Red flags below as per ACR update 2021 -systematic review based).

scenario: Low velocity trauma, osteoporosis, and /or age > 70 years, X-ray NAD or nil unexpected
Suspicion of cancer, infection, or immunosuppression, XR NAD/ non-contributory.
Low back pain and/or radiculopathy, surgery or intervention candidate, XR NAD or nil unexpected.
Prior lumbar surgery, XR NAD or nil unexpected.
Spinal infection
Follow up, new symptoms
Follow up, routine, no new symptoms
Spinal stenosis
Follow up, no red flags*
Plexopathy
Brachial - acute onset or chronic plexopathy without trauma, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Brachial - entrapment syndromes, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Brachial - post-treatment syndrome, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Lumbosacral - acute onset or chronic plexopathy without trauma, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Lumbosacral - entrapment syndrome, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Lumbosacral - post-treatment syndrome, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Myelopathy (see neuro also)
Painful
Stepwise progressive
Slowly progressive, XR NAD or nil unexpected findings
Oncology patient
Stress insufficiency fractures including sacrum
Suspect stress/insufficiency fracture.  First imaging modality.
Suspect stress fracture in patient with need-to-know diagnosis, not hip or sacrum.  X-rays normal.
Suspect stress fracture, not hip or sacrum. X-rays normal.  Bone scan positive and nonspecific.
Suspect stress fracture in otherwise normal patient. X-rays and bone scan or MRI normal.
Clinical differential insufficiency fracture versus metastasis in sacrum.  X-rays normal, bone scan hot but nonspecific.
Suspect insufficiency fracture in sacrum/pelvis; elderly patient.  X-rays normal. Bone scan hot in a linear pattern typical for fracture.
Suspect insufficiency fracture in osteoporotic patient or patient on long-term corticosteroid therapy, not hip. X-rays normal.
Suspect insufficiency fracture in osteoporotic patient or patient on long-term corticosteroid therapy; not hip. X-rays and bone scan or MRI normal at 48 hours.
Suspect sub-acute insufficiency fracture of hip in osteoporotic patient or patient on corticosteroid therapy.  X-rays normal.
Chronic neck pain
Patient of any age, without a history of previous trauma, first study.
Patient of any age, history of previous malignancy, first study.
Patient of any age, history of previous neck surgery, no red flags, first study.
comments: If any red flags, then P2

scenario: X-rays normal. No neurologic findings.
X-rays normal. Neurologic signs or symptoms present.
X-rays show spondylosis. No neurologic findings.
X-rays show spondylosis. Neurologic signs or symptoms present.
X-rays show old trauma. No neurologic findings.
X-rays show old trauma. Neurologic signs or symptoms present.
X-rays show bone or disc margin destruction.

* Red Flags - as per ACR Update Nov 2021 
Clinical features suggesting infection: temp>38, elevated ESR and CRP, Immunosuppressed patients
Suspicion/ risk factors of osteoporotic fracture - age>70 (especially female), history of minor trauma, Long-term corticosteroid use
History of bone-metastasizing cancer 
Bowel or bladder incontinence

scenario: Right upper quadrant pain
No fever, normal WBC
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: No fever, normal WBC, ultrasound shows only gallstones
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Palpable abdominal mass
Palpable mass, high suspicion of cancer clinically
comments: Acute <24 hrs  to Sub-acute, Urgent , complete imaging  within  48 hrs to 1 week of receiving referral, non-deferrable

scenario: Palpable mass, low-mod clinical suspicion for cancer or pulsatile and painless
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral  to within 6 weeks

scenario: Jaundice
Painless, one or more of the following: weight loss, fatigue, anorexia, duration of symptoms greater than 3 months.  Patient otherwise healthy.
comments: Acute <24 hrs  to Sub-acute, Urgent , complete imaging  within  48 hrs to 1 week of receiving referral, non-deferrable to within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Painless, one or more of the following: weight loss, fatigue, anorexia, duration of symptoms greater than 3 months.  Patients who will not tolerate radical surgical procedure.
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Clinical condition and laboratory examination make mechanical obstruction unlikely.
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Confusing clinical picture, patient not described in previous scenarios.
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Liver lesion characterisation
Typical benign on initial imaging, no history of malignancy
Typical benign on initial imaging, known history of extrahepatic malignancy
Typical malignant hepatic mass on initial imaging
comments: Acute <24 hrs  to Sub-acute, Urgent , complete imaging  or intervention within  48 hrs to 1 week of receiving referral, non-deferrable or  must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Indeterminate on initial imaging, 1cm, no suspicion or evidence of extrahepatic malignancy or liver disease
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral to within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Indeterminate solitary mass on initial imaging, >1cm, known history of extrahepatic malignancy
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Indeterminate mass on initial imaging, >1cm, known or suspected liver disease associated with a high risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, hemochromatosis, etc)
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Small lesion on initial imaging, <1cm
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Suspected liver metastases
Initial imaging test following detection of primary tumour
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Surveillance following treatment of primary tumour
comments: Deferrable, time-sensitive imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of a specified target date

scenario: Abnormal surveillance US, CT or MRI, or PVP: high suspicion of malignancy
comments: Deferrable, time-sensitive imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of a specified target date

scenario: Crohn's disease
Adult with known Crohn's disease and fever, increasing pain, leucocytosis etc
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Adult with known Crohn's disease; stable, mild symptoms
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Dysphagia
Oropharyngeal dysphagia with an attributable cause
Unexplained oropharyngeal dysphagia
Retrosternal dysphagia in immunocompetent patients
Retrosternal dysphagia in immunocompromised patients
Dysmotility
Miscellaneous
Malabsorption
Cirrhosis
Pancreatic tumour
Oesophageal tumour
Scrotum/ testicular
Testis tumour (diagnosed by orchidectomy)
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Acute pyelonephritis
Uncomplicated episode in female patient
Urinary tract calculi
Follow-up small stones < 4mm
comments: Deferrable, time-sensitive imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of a specified target date

scenario: Male UTI
Adult male who has a recurrent or persistent infection, or a single episode of pyelonephritis
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Female UTI
Adult females who are non-responders to prophylactic antibiotics AND get frequent reinfections (≥2 in 6 months OR ≥ 3 in 1 year)
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Haematuria
Patients >40 years and <85 years with painless macroscopic haematuria and eGFR >45
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Patients >40 years and <85 years with lab-confirmed microscopic  haematuria on >2 occasions and in absence of proteinuria, pyuria and eGFR>45
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Patients <40 years or >85 years with macroscopic haematuria or confirmed microscopic haematuria
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Renal failure
Chronic renal failure and eGFR <30 or <45 with diabetes, or progressive drop in eGFR>5 over 12 months or with significant proteinuria (urine ACR>30) or associated haematuria.
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Obstructed voiding secondary to prostate disease
modality: Obstructed voiding secondary to prostate disease
priority: Obstructed voiding secondary to prostate disease
comments: Obstructed voiding secondary to prostate disease

scenario: Normal renal function
Reduced eGFR, suspected urinary retention
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Renal lesions
Cyst or hyperdense cyst characterisation
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: RCC ≤ 3 cm characterisation + stage
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: RCC > 3 cm characterisation + stage
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Post-surgical RCC, asymptomatic patient; no known metastases
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Bladder lesions
Pre-treatment TCC
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral to P3 or even P4 depending on cystoscopy findings

scenario: F/U Superficial TCC; no invasion or risk factors.
comments: Deferrable, time-sensitive imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6-12  weeks of a specified target date

scenario: F/U Invasive TCC with or without cystectomy.
comments: Deferrable, time-sensitive imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of a specified target date

scenario: F/U Superficial TCC; no invasion; with risk factors.
comments: Deferrable, time-sensitive imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of a specified target date

scenario: Pre-treatment staging prostate cancer
PSA elevated but <20
PSA>20 and clinical T3
Staging of high-risk prostate cancer
Biochemical recurrence post radical therapy
Renal transplant
CTA for donor transplant
Recipient
Miscellaneous
F/U hydronephrosis
comments: Dependent on age, severity and renal function

scenario: Vascular
Sudden onset of cold, painful leg
Suspected symptomatic AAA
Pulsatile abdominal mass, suspected asymptomatic AAA
comments: US is a validated investigation especially for community referrals

scenario: Claudication - suspected vascular aetiology, failed conservative management (exercise program)
comments: US by vascular sonographer may be considered if not already performed

scenario: Follow-up of lower limb arterial bypass surgery
comments: NB Lengthy deferrals may put grafts at risk

scenario: Recurrent symptoms following lower limb angioplasty - claudication
Recurrent symptoms following lower limb angioplasty - threatened limb
Neurological event suspected carotid disease
comments: CTA as alternative if vascular US expertise not available.

scenario: Aneurysm/graft surveillance - AAA, visceral, iliac or popliteal
US detected abnormality on stent surveillance
comments: - highly variable depending  on severity of stenosis

scenario: Dialysis fistula - complication suspected including occlusion, steal, stenosis
Venous incompetence
Diabetic foot
Soft-tissue oedema without ulcer/cellulitis/neuroarthropathy
comments: Deferrable, complete within 6-12 weeks of receiving referral to Deferrable , lowest priority, can wait 12 weeks

scenario: Neuroarthropathy without ulceration
comments: Non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 6 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Neuroarthropathy with ulceration but no infection
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral (up to <3 weeks)

scenario: Deteriorating ulceration with evidence of arterial disease
comments: Urgent , non-deferrable imaging or intervention that must be completed within 2 weeks of receiving referral

scenario: Ulcer with cellulitis/discharging pus/necrosis
comments: Acute  to subacute – from <24-48 hrs to within 1 week
